title: The weirdest jobs in travel revealed
text:

Sleeping on the job is part of the working day for some.
One hotel in New York, for instance, employs a sleep concierge to help guests drift off.
But that's not the only bizarre job in the travel industry. Here MailOnline Travel reveals the quirkiest roles around, from a parrot wrangler to a sunglasses doctor.
Fairy Godmother
The fairy godmother, who was formally the hotel's restaurant manager, specialises in proposals
At the Barnsley Resort in Adairsville, Georgia, lives Denise Webb - the hotel's fairy godmother.
The role, which was bestowed upon her by former hotel owner Prince Hubertus Fugger of Bavaria, includes creating once-in-a-lifetime experiences for guests such as recreating honeymoons and surprises for both people and animals.

Ms Webb said: 'Prince Hubertus Fugger of Bavaria sat me down on a very special rock in the woodland gardens and made me a Fairy Godmother.
'Then he gave me my own very special crystal wand and charged me with enchanting peopleâ€™s stay.'
Sunglasses doctor
Shady character: The in-house repairman claims to be able to fix and clean anything from Ray-Ban to Chanel to Gucci
Broken sunglasses? No problem. At the Four Seasons Resort Lanai in Hawaii Dr Shades in on hand poolside from sunrise to sunset.
The in-house repairman claims to be able to fix and clean anything from Ray-Ban to Chanel to Gucci.
Dr Shades makes his way around the resort carrying a medical bag equipped with complimentary loaner shades and tools.
Coconut engineer
One hotel employs coconut engineers who climb the trees on a regular basis to harvest the nuts
Fancy sunbathing beneath a palm tree? Well at the Ritz-Carlton in St. Thomas you can - safely.
The hotel employs coconut engineers who climb the trees on a regular basis to harvest the nuts and ensure none are loose.
Not only does this keep things safe for guests and employees below, it also means the engineers will cut open the coconuts, then serve them to guests (with or without rum).
Dog surfing instructor
Pets can now take to the waves alongside others - the only rule being that they must not have a fear of water
For those with pets who need a hand getting on the board - look no further than Loews Coronado Resort and Spa in San Diego.
Teevan McManus of Conorado Surfing Academy was hired as the resort's professional dog surfing instructor in 2005 after he was spotted in the ocean with his dog, Murphy.
Pampered pets can now take to the waves alongside others - the only rule being that the dog must not have a fear of water.
Teevan McManus of Conorado Surfing Academy was hired as a professional dog surfing instructor in 2005
Mr McManus said: 'I used to have a German Shorthair Pointer named Murphy.
'He would come to the beach with me and try to follow me out in the water while I surfed.
'It was just a matter of time before I started to put him on the board and allow him to catch his own waves.
'There is no official training to get or perform this job... however, just like any other teaching job it requires a great deal of patience.'
Social media butler
Want to broadcast those special moments on social media but don't fancy going to the trouble of typing the captions and hashtags?
Help is at hand.
The Madison Hotel in Washington DC offers a butler who is specifically there to follow you around and update you on your social media.
This means that when you're out partying or exploring, you can call on your butler to take the shot and tweet it out to your followers without having to reach for your phone.
Proposal coach
Well aisle never: Stowe Mountain Lodge in Vermont employs Wendy Collins to assist with proposals
Wendy Collins is there for people suffering from pre-wedding jitters at Stowe Mountain Lodge in Vermont.
This job consists of guiding hopeful husbands and wives through every detail from deciding a date to getting down on one knee.
Ms Collins runs the complimentary service from the lodge and said her aim is to stop the nerves and make the moment one to remember.
Ms Collins said: 'Where the proposal takes place really creates the moment for couple and a lasting memory.
'The craziest proposal I have ever seen was when a couple had a weekend planned in Stowe and last minute the groom could not make it on the trip.
'Upon arrival the bride was surprised with a full day of pampering salon treatments. She was thrilled and just thought he was making up for not being there on the trip. D
'At the end of the most luxurious day she had a reservation for a waterfall hike and happened to be the only one that showed up.
'The groom was waiting on one knee at the base of the waterfall. She was so excited and amazed.'
Resort Aviarist
Bruno cares for birds and wanders around the Four Seasons Resort Lanai in Hawaii with them
Bruno Amby has a few feathers to his bow - he looks after birds at the Four Seasons Resort Lanai in Hawaii.
Three rescued birds - KeO KeO, Ola and Hauoli - all live on the resort as part of their Rescue Bird Programme.
Bruno cares for the creatures, who will now permanently live at the resort, and wanders around the hotel with them full time.
Manners police
Decorum monitors were deployed in Venice's St Mark's Square this year to keep tourists in line with local customs and manners.
The manners police patrol the city and watch out for people wearing bathing suits in the city, feeding the pigeons in St Mark's Square and buying fake goods from street vendors.
Signs around the city have been printed in seven languages in a bid to nudge tourists' behaviour in the right direction.
Sleep concierge
If you are having trouble getting some shut-eye you can call the sleep concierge at The Benjamin in New York City.
Holidaymakers will be given the choice of 13 pillows - from water-filled to buckwheat - which help to fulfil the hotel's pledge to provide a good night's sleep or a free night.
In addition to the pillow menu, the hotel employee will offer guests lavender sprays, pre-bed massages and milk and cookies before they sleep.
A hotel employee at The Benjamin will offer guests lavender sprays, pre-bed massages and milk and cookies
In 2010 hotel chain Holiday Inn went one step further and deployed human bed warmers. Instead of electric blankets and hot water bottles, staff dressed in special all-in-one sleeper suits were sent to warm beds before guests got under the covers.
However, after a short trial period - the service was withdrawn.
